jauntyc.analysis.lexer

Interface Lexer

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    EditableLexer
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    LexerWrapper, StandardLexer

    public interface Lexer
extends java.lang.Cloneable
    Defines the interface of a generic lexer.

    A lexer is thought to recognize the membership of tokens to some "type", defined through some notation, such as regular expressions.

    A lexer is generically non editable. This interface does not provide any modifier method for the lex rules (see EditableLexer).

    A token might match multiple types, and each matched type might refer to a certain token with a certain length.

    For instance:
    • Three token types could be defined:
      • - "double": matches double precision floating points (e.g. "31.4");
      • - "integer": matches integer number (e.g. "15");
      • - "ip": matches an Internet Protocol Address (e.g. "192.168.1.1");
    • the token "23.57.72.4":
      • - matches the type "double" as "23.57";
      • - matches the type "integer" as "23";
      • - matches the type "ip" as "23.57.72.4";
    Author:
    Salvatore Giampà

    • Method Detail

      • setInput

        void setInput(java.lang.String input)
        Sets the input string for this lexer
        Parameters:
        input - the string to lex

      • token

        java.lang.String token(java.lang.String type)
        Recognizes if the last discovered tokens is a member of the specified type group.
        This method should be used after a call to the next() method.

        For example:
        • if there are three types, "double", "integer" and "letters", the token "38.5" would match the type "double" as "38.5" and the type "integer" as "38", but not the type "string".
          Then at position 0 of the token " 38.5 " (note the spaces before character '3' and after character '5'):
          • the call token("double") will return "38.5";
          • the call token("integer") will return "38";
          • the call token("string") will return null;
        This method is useful to be used by a parser, searching for the next expected token type.
        Parameters:
        type - the name of the token type
        Returns:
        the token that matches the type or null if no token was found for the specified type, at the first position where another one matched

      • token

        java.lang.String token()
        Get the token that matches the default type of the matched types. Generally the default token type is the matched type witch was first added to the lexer rules. The default type definition could change for some implementations.
        Returns:
        the token that is member of the default type.

      • tokenType

        java.lang.String tokenType()
        Get the default matched token type. Generally the default token type is the one of matched types witch was first added to the lexer rules. The default type definition could change for some implementations.
        Returns:
        the token that is member of the default type.

      • similarTypes

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> similarTypes()
        Get the set of token types which matched a tokent at the current position.
        Returns:
        the set of possible matching types

      • start

        int start()
        Get the start position of all matched types. It is the same for all currently matched type.
        Returns:
        the start position of the matching

      • end

        int end()
        Get the end position of the currently matched type. It is the end of the token matching the default type just after a call to the next() method, or the length of the token matching the type just passed to the token(String) method.
        Returns:
        the end position of the current matching token

      • setStart

        void setStart(int position)
        Set the start position of the next computation of the next() method.
        Parameters:
        position - the start position to set

      • input

        java.lang.String input()
        Get the input string setted by the setInput(String) method.
        Returns:
        the input string

      • next

        boolean next()
        Search the next token matching.
        Returns:
        true if a matching was found for some type, false otherwise

      • description

        java.lang.String description(java.lang.String type)
        Get the printable description associated to the specified type.
        Parameters:
        type - the type name
        Returns:
        the description for the specified type

      • regex

        Get the regex associated to the specified type

        Returns:
